text: - Hello everyone, Rahul Kochhar here.

I'm a Partner Solution
Architect here at AWS.

I'm joined today by my
colleague Ron Wedel.
- Thanks, Rahul, yeah, as Rahul said,

I am also a Partner Solutions
Architect here at AWS,
and Rahul and I both work with partners

to really help our customers
leverage native AWS tooling,
and as part of that,
migrate from on-premises into the Cloud.

- Perfect, so Ron, today
we're gonna talk about
one of the ISV partners

that we're working
extensively with, RiverMeadow.
Do you want to give us a quick rundown

on what RiverMeadow is,
what the platform is,

when do we use it, how
do our partners use it?
How do we, RiverMeadow,

and our partners deliver
successful outcomes
to our customers at large and at scale?

- Sure, so RiverMeadow
is more than just a piece

of software that helps the
customer migrate their workloads
from on-premises into the cloud.

They are a suite of professional
services, their platform,
that all comes together to really help

those larger customers exit
their on-premises workloads
and put them into a native AWS solution.
- That really starts with their platform
and then discovery and assessment.

They work with the customers
to do those portions.
Wave planning and intake
of what's gonna be moving to the cloud-

- Sure.
- And how that looks.
Executing on that migration,

as well as integrating with,
or interviewing the customer
and taking a look at those workloads,

if there's any additional
customization or automations

that need to take place
during the migration.
And then post-migration,
they validate that everything was moved,

and then overall
management of the project.
- Yeah, sounds like an exciting solution.

So why don't we dive deep into
the way RiverMeadow works?

If you don't mind,
let's look at a solution

or a example of, "I'm a
customer that runs workload

via virtual and physical
Windows and Linux on-prem,

and I have storage that
is accessed by file
and by block on-prem,

and I would like to bring
that workload over to AWS."
And then we can, you know,
dive deep into that exercise, shall we?
- Yeah, I think we can do that.
Really, it all starts right here
with the RiverMeadow platform.

This is their software
as a service solution.
It all starts there.

You create an account and
then what you're gonna do

is start interacting with
both your destination
and the source of your migration.

So let's start actually
with the AWS side of it.

- All right.
- What you're gonna do

is you're gonna have a
customer with an AWS account.

And what we're gonna do since
that RiverMeadow platform

is deployed and actually
runs on AWS in the backend,
RiverMeadow is going to set up IAM roles,

the trust between your
account and RiverMeadow,
and then deploy a RiverMeadow appliance
inside of your AWS account.

- I think that would be a
virtual appliance, a AMI?
- Yes, a custom AMI

that comes from the RiverMeadow
account gets deployed
into your AWS account.
That's step one.
Step two is we're gonna ensure

that you have network connectivity
between your AWS account
and your on-premises data center.
We'll just call this data center one.
- And with that network connectivity,
you can configure the RiverMeadow platform
of all your destination specifications.
If we were gonna use a use case, VMware,

a lot of customers are
running VMware workloads
on-premises today.
So RiverMeadow will deploy an agent,

another virtual machine,
a virtual appliance,
inside the customer's vSphere environment,
and that will talk to vCenter
and that will allow it to do a lot
of that interrogation of the source,

whether it's the virtual
machines, their performance,
everything that it can pull out of vCenter
and that's how it starts interacting
in a very base level interaction.
- Does that agent in this example. in DC1,

does it also talk to the, the
RiverMeadow SaaS platform?
- Yes, it does.
And it actually will talk back
through the RiverMeadow appliance in AWS.

- All right, and it
would be fair to assume
that it's a secure connection.
- Yeah, it is.

It's all connected
through SSL certificates
between the RiverMeadow appliance
and the RiverMeadow platform.

- All right, now tell
me if I heard you right,

if I have another data
center, say for example,
in a different location,

does that mean I'm gonna
deploy another agent
that's gonna connect to my AWS?

- Exactly.
- Right.

- You configure in the
RiverMeadow platform

the other destination, if it
was, say, a second data center,

the only-
- The other source?

- Yeah, the other source.
- Yeah.

- So if this was, say,
DC2, you could connect it.
Again, the key is making sure
that there is network connectivity
between your source and your destination.
- All right, perfect.

Now talking about destination,
imagine if I am a customer

and I am doing this
migration across regions

and then bringing all
those different regions
into different AWS regions, right?
So now I have another AWS region, right?
Say this is region two.
Would it be fair to assume that, you know,
we could then deploy another destination-

- Absolutely.
- For the workload so that...
- Again, it would be the same token.

You would set up the new,
the additional AWS account
or region in this case,

in RiverMeadow and it
would deploy another AMI

and it would handle
coordinating that destination.
- So we spoke about the architecture,
the flexibility, the ability to adapt

to a multi-tiered,
multi-regional architecture.
Talk to me about that agent.
What is the purpose of that agent?

And you know, is that the
only agent that we deploy

to get the data or the
inventory of you know,
what's in vSphere?
Or do we need to also deploy an agent
on the individual virtual machines?
- No, traditionally for most workloads,
this agent would be sufficient.
It can interact with vCenter
through all the same storage APIs

that, say, traditional
backup software does.

It's able to take
snapshots, replicate data,

it asks vCenter about long-term,
30 days of performance,
to really provide some
of those right-sizing recommendations.
But if there's a use case

where potentially you don't
have access to vCenter,

you can put an agent, a
very lightweight agent,
on each of your workloads,

whether those are virtual
machines or physical.
And that will interact with RiverMeadow
just like the traditionally,

and allow you to, say,
exit a situation maybe
where you no longer have rights
to the underlying infrastructure,
you wanna migrate to the cloud.

- So you, you know,
mentioned about right sizing,

does that mean that, A, if
I'm running, say for example,
a very large virtual machine,
which was deployed way back when,
and now that we realize that using this
during the migration,
we wanna also use this as an opportunity
to resize a workload.
Could we resize while we are in that mode
of consolidating our workload together?

- Absolutely, and again,
that comes from the fact
that this agent in this specific use case
is talking to vCenter.
It's looking at the performance statistics

of the virtual machine
over the last 30 days.
So it can take a recommendation

of you have whatever the
specs were on-premises,
but maybe it needs half of that.

And it'll help, it will
recommend the specific target
instance type in AWS because as you know,

in AWS we base our EC2
workloads on instance types

and RiverMeadow will make
a recommendation based

on the data it's ingested to
right size at the destination.
- Is there a recommended timeline?

Like how long you want to
have that agent running
and collecting the data?
- Well, see, that's the great thing

when we're talking
about vCenter workloads,
vCenter already has the data.

- All right.
- So it can ask vCenter
for the previous 30 days worth of data
and make a recommendation on that.
Now if this was an installed agent,

obviously you would want to
give it time to go through
and take a look at performance based

on whatever the application's
use is defined by.

- All right, so we
spoke about right sizing
the operating system.
Now what, you know, typically customers
that are running those workloads on-prem
also have some operating systems

that cannot be brought over
to AWS in the native format

because maybe that is a
Windows 2008 operating system
or Windows server 2012 R2,

which is not supported
as an EC2 form factor.
How do we do a OS transformation?

- Well actually RiverMeadow
calls it OS modernization.
You can take anything as far back
as a Windows server 2003 virtual machine
and upgrade it in flight,

validate the upgrade all
the way up to server 2022,
and then cutover.

So it provides you the
ability to replicate the data,
upgrade the operating system,

validate the upgrade before
you even do a cutover.
If the upgrade failed for whatever reason,

perhaps there was a software
that just isn't working,
the source machine stays the same.

It's never impacted by
that upgrade during flight.
- Okay, so right sizing, taken care of.
Optimizing, we spoke about that.

Doing in-flight upgrades,
that makes sense.
How about, say for example,

I am running a few
licensed version of Linux

and I would like to also
use this opportunity

to do consolidate my, say
for example, licensing.
And say, "Hey, you know what?
I wanna go to more open source, you know,
Linux distribution, like CentOS.

- Yeah, RiverMeadow allows
you to do that as well.
They have the same ability
with modernizing Windows for workloads,
They have the ability

to convert Linux operating
systems in flight.

Filing a very similar
pathway of replicating,
changing the operating system,
allowing you as the customer to validate

the change as successful before
you do your final cutover.
- That's great.

We spoke at length about
the operating systems.

You know, typically most of
the operating systems on-prem,
are learning workload, but you know,
also they run one of the other workloads
is a database server.
So imagine if it's a SQL server,
and let's just now mix the two use cases
of SQL server and SQL Server 2008,
you know, which is also end of life.
How does that run?
- Same way, we've already gone over it.
They will take the software,
they will upgrade it in flight,
make sure that it's validated and working,
and then allow you to cutover.
So their tools and tooling

in the RiverMeadow platform
really does take a lot

of the risk of some of
those legacy systems away

as you move into the cloud.
- Great!

Well Ron, I think I have
my questions answered.
If we need to go to the next steps,
how would they get in touch with us?

If you're a customer,
